block.p: The criticism in the Personal Health column on Oct. 3 of parents who question the ''safety and wisdom of childhood immunizations'' seems unfair.

No knowledgeable parent objects to immunizations for measles, polio or whooping cough. More questionable are newer vaccines for less significant diseases. Pharmaceutical companies lead aggressive campaigns for new immunizations.
The criticism in the Personal Health column on Oct. 3 of parents who question the ''safety and wisdom of childhood immunizations'' seems unfair.

No knowledgeable parent objects to immunizations for measles, polio or whooping cough. More questionable are newer vaccines for less significant diseases. Pharmaceutical companies lead aggressive campaigns for new immunizations.
But a new vaccine for an intestinal virus in infants was withdrawn last year after some recipients had intestinal complications.
Parents may rightfully be concerned by annual recommendations for vaccines of questionable value, safety and necessity whenever a drug company develops one.
DR. LONNIE B. HANAUER Millburn, N.J.
